I developed an appreciation for the Bhagavad Gita as a religious text and had the opportunity to read it for the first time. I derived many meaningful lessons from the Gita, and found it to be an enlightening experience. The weekly discussion posts allowed me to engage with the text and ask questions to the professor that always elicited interesting responses. Overall, I developed an appreciation for and understanding of Hindu theology as it relates to the Bhagavad Gita.
The course provides an overview of the main themes and teachings of the Gita.
You learn a lot about India's religious history and the Gita is a interesting text if you allow yourself time to get used to it.

a deeper understanding of the Bhagavad Gita

Terrific professor.

The strength of this course is its consistent schedule and workload, which allows students the ability to closely analyze one book of the Gita every week and interpret its meaning. Yet another strength of the course is that the content lends itself to writing papers about the Gita, which were incredibly rewarding. Since Professor Flick encourages students to write about their own personal journeys to find meaning, writing the papers for this class was incredibly compelling.
I feel like this course should be structured a smaller seminar, especially since because of the large class size, many many people did other stuff on their laptops. Strength: Prof. Flick.
I appreciated that the course's structure allowed for detailed discussions of each book of the Gita. I don't see any major weaknesses in the course.

Well organized, curated, and thought out weekly reading list! In class lessons were thought out, comprehensive and include student reading responses.
I just wish it could have more student-student/peer-peer discussion, but I also know that religion can be a sensitive subject so it can be hard to be open about it...
A bit too large of a class for conducive discussion. Discussion posts weekly helped to alleviate that, but still not the same as being able to exchange in back and forth dialogue in person.

The course is well taught, and the translation is written by Prof Flick himself. This is a strength, because we can discuss the text directly with the author, and the weekly discussion forms are helpful in getting to read the thoughts of others in the class too.
Strengths- the pace of the readings makes it very easy to follow along and really dive deep into the narrative.
I really appreciated the freedom that Professor Flcik provided throughout the course in being able to explore different texts and perspectives on the Gita.
weaknesses - I wish we did more small group discussions, because talking directly to such a large class was intimidating
The class did not have much workload and the readings were interesting. The class met only once a week for almost two hours and lectures could get a little dry.

I really enjoyed the way that Professor Flick conducted the class. He would answer the questions that we posed in the discussion forum at the end of the class. I think the only way the class could be improved is greater accessibility to those who did not grow up studying the Gita. I know that the assumed prior knowledge discouraged some people from taking the class though it would have been beneficial for them.
No weaknesses. Everything is amazing.

YES.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in the Bhagavad Gita and is willing to challenge their assumptions and viewpoints regarding the world. The Gita most definitely changed my approach to many facets of my life, and if you are an open person, you will find yourself growing both personally and intellectually by taking this course.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in Indian philosophy.
